scenarioDescription:
The HD 40307 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 40307 is a star with 0.77 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.72 times its radius. It is located 42.19 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.5 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 40307 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 40307 system


HD 40307 b

HD 40307 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2009-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 40307 b is 4.007 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 40307 b is 1.830 that of Earth. At 4.007 Earth masses, HD 40307 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


HD 40307 c

HD 40307 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2009-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 40307 c is 6.614 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 40307 c is 2.460 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 40307 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 40307 d

HD 40307 d was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2009-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 40307 d is 9.508 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 40307 d is 3.040 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 40307 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 40307 f

HD 40307 f was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2013-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.25 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 40307 f is 5.215 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 40307 f is 2.130 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 40307 f is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 40307 g

HD 40307 g was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2013-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.60 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 40307 g is 7.091 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 40307 g is 2.560 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 40307 g is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 40307, which contains 5 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: HD 40307 - System With 5 Exoplanets
